pageProps.contentHtml:
measure theory, monotone functions

Suppose f ⁣:R→R\func{f}{\R}{\R}f:R→R is non-decreasing; specifically, for x,y∈Rx, y \in \Rx,y∈R we have the implication

x≤y  ⟹  f(x)≤f(y).x \leq y \implies f\p{x} \leq f\p{y}.x≤y⟹f(x)≤f(y).

Show that if A⊆RA \subseteq \RA⊆R is a Borel set, then so is f(A)={f(x)∣x∈A}f\p{A} = \set{f\p{x} \mid x \in A}f(A)={f(x)∣x∈A}.
Solution.

Since fff is monotone, it is continuous except at countably many points DDD, hence Borel. For each x∈Dx \in Dx∈D, define f+(x)=lim⁡y→x+f(y)f_+\p{x} = \lim_{y \to x^+} f\p{y}f+​(x)=limy→x+​f(y) and f−(x)=lim⁡y→x−f(y)f_-\p{x} = \lim_{y \to x^-} f\p{y}f−​(x)=limy→x−​f(y). By modifying fff on a countable set, we may assume without loss of generality that f−(x)=f(x)f_-\p{x} = f\p{x}f−​(x)=f(x), i.e., fff is left continuous. Then given x∈Dx \in Dx∈D, let

Ix=(f−(x),f+(x)]∖Ux,I_x = \poc{f_-\p{x}, f_+\p{x}} \setminus U_x,Ix​=(f−​(x),f+​(x)]∖Ux​,

where Ux={f+(x)}U_x = \set{f_+\p{x}}Ux​={f+​(x)} if f+(x)∈f(R)f_+\p{x} \in f\p{\R}f+​(x)∈f(R) and ∅\emptyset∅ otherwise.

We claim that f(R)c=⋃x∈DIxf\p{\R}^\comp = \bigcup_{x \in D} I_xf(R)c=⋃x∈D​Ix​. It's clear that "⊇\supseteq⊇", since fff is monotone and UxU_xUx​ handles the upper endpoint. Conversely, suppose y∉f(R)y \notin f\p{\R}y∈/f(R). Let x−=sup⁡ {x∣f(x)<y}x_- = \sup\,\set{x \mid f\p{x} < y}x−​=sup{x∣f(x)<y} and x+=inf⁡ {x∣f(x)>y}x_+ = \inf\,\set{x \mid f\p{x} > y}x+​=inf{x∣f(x)>y}. We claim that x−=x+x_- = x_+x−​=x+​: otherwise, x−<x+x_- < x_+x−​<x+​, so let x∈(x−,x+)x \in \p{x_-, x_+}x∈(x−​,x+​). Since x>x−x > x_-x>x−​, this means f(x)≥yf\p{x} \geq yf(x)≥y, and because x<x+x < x_+x<x+​, f(x)≤yf\p{x} \leq yf(x)≤y, so f(x)=yf\p{x} = yf(x)=y, which is a contradiction. Thus, x=x−=x+x = x_- = x_+x=x−​=x+​, which means f−(x)≤y≤f+(x)f_-\p{x} \leq y \leq f_+\p{x}f−​(x)≤y≤f+​(x).

Since y∉f(R)y \notin f\p{\R}y∈/f(R), this means that f−(x)<yf_-\p{x} < yf−​(x)<y. On the other hand, if y=f+(x)y = f_+\p{x}y=f+​(x), then f+(x)∉f(R)  ⟹  Ix=(f−(x),f+(x)]f_+\p{x} \notin f\p{\R} \implies I_x = \poc{f_-\p{x}, f_+\p{x}}f+​(x)∈/f(R)⟹Ix​=(f−​(x),f+​(x)]. If y≠f+(x)y \neq f_+\p{x}y=f+​(x), then y∈(f−(x),f+(x))⊆Ixy \in \p{f_-\p{x}, f_+\p{x}} \subseteq I_xy∈(f−​(x),f+​(x))⊆Ix​. Hence, f(R)c=⋃x∈DIxf\p{\R}^\comp = \bigcup_{x \in D} I_xf(R)c=⋃x∈D​Ix​. Thus, f(R)cf\p{\R}^\compf(R)c is a countable union of Borel sets (intervals) hence Borel, which means that f(R)f\p{\R}f(R) is also Borel.

Another important property is that fff is injective after removing a countable set. Indeed, by monotonicity, f−1({y})f^{-1}\p{\set{y}}f−1({y}) is either empty, a singleton, or a non-trivial interval. Let CCC be the set of yyy where f−1({y})f^{-1}\p{\set{y}}f−1({y}) is an interval. By density, this contains a rational number r(y)r\p{y}r(y), and if y≠zy \neq zy=z, then f−1({y})∩f−1({z})=∅f^{-1}\p{\set{y}} \cap f^{-1}\p{\set{z}} = \emptysetf−1({y})∩f−1({z})=∅, so r(y)≠r(z)r\p{y} \neq r\p{z}r(y)=r(z), i.e., y↦r(y)y \mapsto r\p{y}y↦r(y) is an injection, so CCC is countable.

Let F={A∣f(A) is Borel}\mathcal{F} = \set{A \mid f\p{A} \text{ is Borel}}F={A∣f(A) is Borel}. We will show that F\mathcal{F}F is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra containing the closed intervals.

Given [a,b]\br{a, b}[a,b], monotonicity of fff implies

f([a,b])=[f(a),f(b)]∩f(R),f\p{\br{a, b}} = \br{f\p{a}, f\p{b}} \cap f\p{\R},f([a,b])=[f(a),f(b)]∩f(R),

which is an intersection of Borel sets, so F\mathcal{F}F contains closed intervals.

First, it's clear that ∅∈F\emptyset \in \mathcal{F}∅∈F. We also know that ⋃n=1∞f(An)=f(⋃n=1∞An)\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty f\p{A_n} = f\p{\bigcup_{n=1}^\infty A_n}⋃n=1∞​f(An​)=f(⋃n=1∞​An​) for any collection of sets. Thus, to show that F\mathcal{F}F is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra, we just need to show that it is closed under complements. Let A∈FA \in \mathcal{F}A∈F so that

f(R)=f(A)∪f(Ac).f\p{\R} = f\p{A} \cup f\p{A^\comp}.f(R)=f(A)∪f(Ac).

Notice that if y∈f(A)∩f(Ac)y \in f\p{A} \cap f\p{A^\comp}y∈f(A)∩f(Ac), then there exist x≠x′x \neq x'x=x′ so that f(x)=f(x′)f\p{x} = f\p{x'}f(x)=f(x′), so f=yf = yf=y on an interval containing xxx and x′x'x′. Thus, y∈Cy \in Cy∈C, so f(A)∩f(Ac)f\p{A} \cap f\p{A^\comp}f(A)∩f(Ac) is at most countable which means

f(Ac)=f(A)c∪(f(A)∩f(Ac))f\p{A^\comp} = f\p{A}^\comp \cup \p{f\p{A} \cap f\p{A^\comp}}f(Ac)=f(A)c∪(f(A)∩f(Ac))

is Borel, so Ac∈FA^\comp \in \mathcal{F}Ac∈F. Thus, F\mathcal{F}F is a σ\sigmaσ-algebra containing closed intervals, so F\mathcal{F}F contains all Borel sets.
